article.description: Jason Williams had 19 points, 12 assists and nine rebounds as the Grizzlies won for the fourth time in five games by beating the hapless Heat 91-86 Friday night.

related.description:
Pat Riley talks about rallying his woeful Miami
Heat and competing for a playoff spot. He talks about rebuilding. He talks about making a big splash in the free-agent market in 2003. He does not talk like a coach about to quit.
related.linkText: Heat coach Riley near boiling point?
related.title: Heat coach's plans a hot topic
related.headline: Heat coach's plans a hot topic

article.headline: Williams powers Grizzlies to fourth win in five games
article.linkText: Riley after latest Heat loss: 'It's not working'
article.story:
MIAMI (AP) -- The Memphis Grizzlies are everything the Miami Heat are not -- young, energetic and, lately, winning. Jason Williams had 19 points, 12 assists and nine rebounds as the Grizzlies won for the fourth time in five games by beating the hapless Heat 91-86 Friday night. The Heat lost their fifth in a row and their second in two nights to fall to 5-22, the second-worst record in the NBA, ahead of only the Chicago Bulls. The Heat have already surpassed the 21 losses coach Pat Riley endured in 1996-97, his best season at Miami. "It's not working," Riley said. "That's all there is to it. We're fumbling and stumbling around." The Heat lost at home for the 11th time in the past 12 games. "Unconscionable," Riley said. "That's absolutely ridiculous for them not to able to win enough games here at home, to have enough enthusiasm and fire and create something here that at least will allow you to withstand poor play on the road." Memphis has only nine wins all season but four since Dec. 20, partly because of Williams' improved play at point guard. "Early in the year, I think he thought he was still playing with the Sacramento Kings," said teammate Shane Battier. "He had to learn that we have some young guys, and patience is the key with this team. He has been much more patient the past six or seven games." Williams said he learned after the game that he came within a rebound of a triple-double. "I'm not really worried about my stats, with the exception of turnovers, which wasn't very good said," said Williams, who had six turnovers. "But I'll take it as long as we win." Grant Long scored 16 points for Memphis and Battier added 15, all in the second half. "We've figured out what each of us can do better," Battier said. "We're getting more comfortable with each other and now we are playing some good basketball." Alonzo Mourning had 20 points and 12 rebounds for the Heat, who committed 20 turnovers and were outscored 22-6 at the free-throw line. For the 27th time in as many games the Heat failed to score 100 points, breaking the franchise record of 26 consecutive games shy of 100 set three seasons ago. The NBA record is 29 in a row, shared by Orlando in 1997-98 and Chicago two seasons ago. The Heat, who blew 19-point second-half lead Thursday at Atlanta, appeared still dazed by that defeat at the outset. They started with five missed shots, four turnovers and a technical foul on Mourning for arguing a call. When Mourning blocked a shot later in the first quarter, he screamed and pumped his arms wildly, trying to fire up his team and the subdued crowd. But that was as much excitement as the Heat could generate. Battier's first two baskets, both 3-pointers, gave Memphis a 54-42 lead early in the second half. He scored again to give the Grizzlies their biggest edge, 63-48. Miami scored eight consecutive points to cut the margin to 72-67 with 10 minutes left but could get no closer until the final 20 seconds. When Memphis committed three consecutive turnovers down the stretch, each time Miami failed to answer with a score. "We just didn't give ourselves a chance," Heat forward Jim Jackson said.

Game notes
Miami fell to 1-6 on the second night of back-to-back games. ... Williams has made 21 consecutive free throws. ... Mourning sank a free throw in the third quarter to end a streak of seven consecutive misses. ... Battier went 5-for-10 in the second half, including one basket where he landed in the first row after being fouled.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
